term_definitions.items: Details of personal name of an individual, provider or third party.
Name in free text unstructured format.
Name previously used by this person.
Name given to this person at birth.
Other name used by this person.
Name used by this persion before marriage.
The date interval at which this name was valid.
The prefix or title used by the subject.
Additional term used following a person name.
The name used by the subject for business or professional purposes.
The name by which the subject is officially registered.
The subjectâs name as it is to be used for reporting, when used with a specific identifier.
Indicates that this is the name by which a person chooses to be identified.
Professional demographics details including name(s) , addresse(s) and telecommunication contact details.
The employment grade or position of the carer.
Team to which the individual belongs.
The period during which this professional was involved in care of the subject.
Personal name details of the individual.
Professional role details of the individual.
Organisation details to which the individual is attached.
Details about a contact person within organisation.

item.list: Date and time of last anamnesis by gynecologist

term_definitions.items: Additional contextual detail to be applied to all compositions.
Date and time of last anamnesis by gynecologist
Very heavy menstrual flow, often causing additional problems such as flooding and clotting.
Record information about a menstural cyclea single day within a menstrual cycle.
Date of onset of menstrual bleeding in a single cycle.
End date of menstrual bleeding in a single cycle.
Details of menstrual bleeding/symptoms on a specific day, eg in a menstrual diary.
Details about symptoms related to menses. For example, menstrual cramps or headaches.
Identify concurrent hormone or intrauterine contraception use. Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Duration of menstrual bleeding in a single cycle or typical duration over many cycles.
Length of single menstrual cycle or typical length over many cycles.
Narrative description of the menstrual cycle as a whole.
Narrative description of the menstrual bleeding.
Qualitative description of amount of menstrual flow.
Presence of blood clots in the menstrual flow.
Presence of heavy menstrual flow that exceeded capacity of sanitary napkins and other menstrual products to absorb the menstrual flow.
Details about the type and amount of sanitary products used.
Number of products needed per day to absorb menstrual flow.
Details of typical menstrual pattern over multiple cycles.
Use of napkin suited for heavy menstrual flow.
Use of a napkin suited for 'normal' menstrual flow.
Use of a napkin suited to very light menstrual flow or spotting.
Use of tampon suited for heavy menstrual flow.
Use of tampon suited for 'normal' menstrual flow.
Use of a cloth pad or towel.
Date of onset of menstrual bleeding in the last normal menstrual cycle.
Summary information about a woman's use of contraception during her lifetime.
Individual has previously used contraception but is not a current user.
Individual has never used any type of contraception.
Can be a partial date, for example, only a year.
Date when the woman last used the specified type of contraception.
Can be a partial date, for example, only a year.
The date, or partial date, when the woman first started using contraception on a regular basis.
Can be a partial date, for example, only a year. For example, this date could represent when the individual commenced smoking every Friday night or at parties.
The date when the woman last stopped using any type of contraception.
Can be a partial date, for example, only a year.
Date when the woman first used the specified type of contraception.
Can be a partial date, for example, only a year.
Additional narrative about all tobacco smoking that has not been captured in other fields.
For example: stopped smoking or reduced amount on becoming pregnant.
The date this contraception summary was last updated.
Identification of the specific contraception used in this episode, by name.

For example: the brand name of the oral contraceptive pill. This data element is most likely redundant in the context of use of some contraceptives such as condoms where specification of the brand or type is usually not relevant.
Intended outcome anticipated as a result of use of the specified contraception.
For example: pregnancy prevention, regular cycle or relief of pain.
Additional structured details about the specified episode of contraception use.
Details about use of a specified type of contraception.

The run-time name constraint on this Cluster enables simple templates for each required type to be designed in templates, or the types to be managed exclusively at run-time. The list of names can be extended at run-time if additional types of contraception are identified locally.
Narrative description of the use for the specified type of contraception during this episode.
This data element may be used to describe the pattern of use, including regularity of use. For example, the oral contraceptive pill was missed frequently or condoms used occasionally.
Narrative summary about the woman's overall use of contraception.

Use this data element to record a narrative description only where the structured data does not adequately reflect the use of contraception for this woman or to incorporate unstructured information from existing or legacy clinical systems into an archetyped format.
Statement about current use of the specified type of contraception.
Narrative summary about the use of the specified type of contraception.
No form of contraception was used.
An oral contraceptive pill containing both an oestrogen and progestin.
An oral contraceptive pill containing only a progestin was used.
The woman's regular sexual partner was surgically sterilised.
Individual has previously used the specified type of contraception but is not a current user.
Individual is a current user of the specified type of contraception.
Details about a discrete period of use for the specified type of contraception.
Clinical reason for using the specified type of contraception during this episode.
For example: dysmennorrhoea; or irregular menses. Coding with an external terminology is preferred, where possible.
Additional narrative about use of the specified type of contraception, not captured in other fields.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Narrative description for the reason for stopping use of the specified type of contraception during this episode.
For example: side effects or becoming pregnant.
The applied definition for the 'Current user' value in each of the 'Status' data elements used in this archetype.
The applied definition for the 'Former user' value in each of the 'Status' data elements used in this archetype.
Additional structured details about the specified type ofcontraception used.
The male partner used a condom.
The applied definition for the 'Never used' value in each of the 'Status' data elements used in this archetype.
Identification of an episode of contraception use - either as a number in a sequence and/or a named event.
For example: '2' as the second episode within a sequence of episodes; or 'Pregnancy with twins' if describing the smoking activity during a health event such as during a specific pregnancy.
Can be a partial date, for example, only a year. This data field will be empty if the episode is current and ongoing.
Additional structured details about the overall use of contraception.
Additional narrative about the use of the specified contraception during the specified episode, not captured in other fields.
An intrauterine device was in situ.
Statement about current use of any type of contraception.
Individual has never used the specified type of contraception.
A depot injection of a progestogen was used.
Abstinence during estimated periods of fertility.
An overview of the obstetric history of a woman, including a summary of all pregnancies and the associated outcomes or interventions.
Number of times a woman has been pregnant, including the current pregnancy, if appropriate.
Number of times a woman has given birth after 20 weeks and 0 days gestation.

Late terminations of pregnancy (after 20 weeks of gestation) are not included. When both 'Term Births (T)' and 'Preterm Births (P)' are recorded, this number should be equal to their sum. Note: Parity is not regarded as the same as the number of infants born - for example, twins would be recorded as one birth event.
Number of times a woman has had a miscarriage at less than 20 weeks of gestation.
Number of times a woman has had a pregnancy terminated, regardless of gestation.
Number of children who remain alive.
The date this summary was last updated.
Note: Stillbirth definition may be optionally captured in specific data element in Protocol.

Maybe useful to record when comparing data from different regions as, as definitions of stillbirth may vary. For example, in Australia a stillborn baby will have a gestation greater than 20 weeks or, if gestation is unknown, weigh more than 400 grams.
Has the woman ever been pregnant?

Record as TRUE if a woman has ever been pregnant. Only useful to record if there is no other detailed data about pregnancies available, or where it may be used to support further knowledge-based activities such as clinical decision support.
Number of infants born on or after 37 weeks of gestation.
Number of infants born at less than 37 weeks of gestation.
Number of non-viable pregnancies from all causes and at any gestation, including miscarriages, induced terminations and ectopic pregnancies.
When all of 'Miscarriages', 'Terminations' and 'Ectopic Pregnancies' are recorded, this number should be equal to their sum.
Number of birth events in which more than one fetus has been born.
Summary or persistent information about the tobacco smoking habit of an individual.
Individual is a current smoker of tobacco.
Individual has previously smoked tobacco but is not a current smoker.
Individual has never smoked any type of tobacco.
Can be a partial date, for example, only a year.
Date when the individual last smoked the specified type of tobacco.

Can be a partial date, for example, only a year. Definitions for a 'Quit date' vary enormously and can be defined using the 'Quit data definition' data element in the Protocol section of this archetype. This date will be identical to the 'Episode end date' for the most recent episode. This date could be used by decision support guidance to determine if the individual is at risk of relapse, for example in the first 12 months since quitting.
The date or partial date when the individual first started frequent or regular, but usually non-daily, smoking of tobacco of any type.
Can be a partial date, for example, only a year. For example, this date could represent when the individual commenced smoking every Friday night or at parties.
The date when the individual last ceased using tobacco of any type.

Can be a partial date, for example, only a year. This date could be used by decision support guidance to determine if the individual is at risk of relapse, for example in the first 12 months since quitting.
Estimate of the cumulative amount of tobacco smoked using the specified type of tobacco.

Commonly used in assessment of cigarette use. It is calculated by multiplying the number of packs of cigarettes smoked per day by the number of years the individual has smoked. One pack year equals 365 packs of cigarettes. Details about how to calculate pack years for other types of tobacco can be found at http://smokingpackyears.com. The definition of a pack can be recorded in the protocol of this archetype using the 'Pack definition' data element.
Additional narrative about all tobacco smoking that has not been captured in other fields.
For example: stopped smoking or reduced amount on becoming pregnant.
The date this tobacco smoking summary was last updated.
Estimate of number of units of the specified type of tobacco consumed.
For example: the number of 'sticks' or 'full pipes' per day or per week. This data element is redundant if a value is recorded for 'Typical use(mass)'.
Total number of times the individual has attempted to stop smoking the specified type of tobacco within this episode.
Additional structured details about the specified episode of tobacco smoking.
Details about smoking activity for a specified type of inhaled tobacco.

The run-time name constraint on this Cluster enables simple templates for each required type to be designed in templates, or the types to be managed exclusively at run-time. The list of names can be extended at run-time if additional types of tobacco smoking are identified locally.
The typical pattern of smoking for the specified type of tobacco.
Narrative summary about the individual's overall tobacco smoking pattern and history.

Use this data element to record a narrative description only where the structured data does not adequately reflect the tobacco smoking habits for this individual or to incorporate unstructured tobacco smoking information from existing or legacy clinical systems into an archetyped format.
Statement about current smoking behaviour for the specified type of tobacco.
Narrative summary about smoking behaviour for the specified type of tobacco.
Also known as manufactured cigarettes, 'factory made' cigarettes or 'tailor made' cigarettes. Processed tobacco, manufactured into cylinder made of paper or a substance that does not contain tobacco.
Also known as "rollies" or "roll-ups". Loose tobacco, hand rolled into a cylinder using cigarette papers.
Also known as "large cigar". Roll of tobacco wrapped within a leaf tobacco or in a substance that contains tobacco.
Loose tobacco placed inside a pipe bowl.
Individual has previously smoked the specified type of tobacco but is not a current smoker.
Individual is a current smoker of the specified type of tobacco.
Also known as "hookah", "shisha", "narguileh" and "hubble-bubble". Tobacco, often flavoured, is burned then cooled through a basin of water and consumed through a hose and mouthpiece.
Details about a discrete period of smoking activity for the specified type of tobacco.
Estimate of the weight of loose leaf tobacco smoked.
This data element will typically be used for pipes and hand-rolled cigarettes and is redundant if a value is recorded for 'Typical use (units)'.
Also known as mini cigars. Short and narrow cigar.
Additional narrative about smoking of the specified type of tobacco, not captured in other fields.
The applied definition for the 'Quit date' data elements used in this archetype.
The definition of the size of pack used as part of the algorithm for calculating 'Pack years' data elements used in this archetype.

Definition may need to be specified per type. For example, the number of units in a pack used for cigarettes may be different to cigars; the mass of loose tobacco in a pack used for hand-rolled cigarettes or pipes.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Estimate of the cumulative amount for all types of tobacco smoked.
The definition of a pack can be recorded in the protocol of this archetype using the 'Pack definition' data element.
The applied definition for the 'Current smoker' value in each of the 'Status' data elements used in this archetype.

Definition may need to be specified per type. Current smoker definitions vary in different jurisdictions. For example: USA Centre for Disease Control refers to smoking during the past one month and New Zealand Ministry of Health uses 28 days.
The applied definition for the 'Former smoker' value in each of the 'Status' data elements used in this archetype.
Definition may need to be specified per type. Former smoker definitions vary in different jurisdictions. For example: New Zealand Ministry of Health refers to smoking during the past 28 days.
Additional structured details about the specified type of tobacco smoking.
Also known as Beedis. Thin hand-rolled cigarettes filled with tobacco and wrapped in a leaf, often tied with colorful string at one or both ends. They can be flavoured or unflavoured.
Additional details could be recorded using the Fagerstrom
The applied definition for the 'Never smoked' value in each of the 'Status' data elements used in this archetype.
Definition may need to be specified per type. For example, the definition may not be zero, but less than a specified amount (as units or mass) smoked during a specified time interval.
The date or partial date when the individual first started daily smoking of tobacco of any type.
Can be a partial date, for example, only a year.
Identification of an episode of smoking activity - either as a number in a sequence and/or a named event.
For example: '2' as the second episode within a sequence of episodes; or 'Pregnancy with twins' if describing the smoking activity during a health event such as during a specific pregnancy.
Can be a partial date, for example, only a year. This data field will be empty if the episode is current and ongoing.
Smoking the specified type of tobacco at least once every day.
Not smoking the specified type of tobacco every day.
The applied definition for a Quit attempt used to determine value for the 'Number of quit attempts' data element used in this archetype.
For example: 'stopped smoking for one day or longer with the intention of quitting'.
Additional structured details about the overall tobacco smoking behaviour.
Additional narrative about tobacco smoking during the specified episode, not captured in other fields.
Also known as clove cigarettes. Cigarettes that contain a mixture of tobacco, cloves and other additives.
Statement about current smoking behaviour for all types of tobacco.
Individual has never smoked the specified type of tobacco.
Narrative summary or overview about a patient, specifically from the perspective of a healthcare provider, and with or without associated interpretations.
The summary, assessment, conclusions or evaluation of the clinical findings.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Request for a health-related service or activity to be delivered by a clinician, organisation or agency.
The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system.
Usually equivalent to the HL7 Placer Order Identifier.
The local identifier assigned to the request by the clinician or organisation receiving the request for service.
Usually equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Identifier.
The date/time, or acceptable interval of date/time, for provision of the service.

This data element allows for recording of the timing for a single service, either as a date and time, a date ranges or a text descriptor which can allow for 'next available. In practice, clinicians will often think in terms of ordering services as approximate timing, for example: review in 3 months, 6 months or 12 months. As clinical systems need more exact parameters to operate on, this '3 months' will usually be converted to an exact date 3 months from the date of recording and stored using this data element. If complex timing or sequences of timings are required, use the CLUSTER.service_direction archetype within the 'Complex timing' SLOT and this data element becomes redundant.
A short phrase describing the reason for the request.

Coding of the 'Reason for request' with a coding system is desirable, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required. For example: 'manage diabetes complications'.
Narrative description about the reason for request.
For example: 'The patient's diabetes has recently become more difficult to stabilise and renal function is deteriorating'.
Description of the intent for the request.

For example: a referral to a specialist may have the intent of the specialist taking over responsibility for care of the patient, or it may be to provide a second opinion on treatment options. Coding of the 'Intent' with a coding system is desirable, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required.
Urgency of the request for service.

Specific definitions of emergency and urgent will vary between clinical contexts, clinical systems and the nature of the request itself, so have not been defined in this archetype. If explicit timing is required then the Service period should be clearly stated.
Supplementary information will be following request.
Record as TRUE if additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available. For example: pending test results.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Language, transport or other personal requirements to support the patient's attendance or participation in provision of the service.
The name of the single service or activity requested.
Coding of the 'Service name' with a coding system is desirable, if available. For example: 'referral' to an endocrinologist for diabetes management.
The status of the request for service as indicated by the requester.
Status is used to denote whether this is the initial request, or a follow-up request to change or provide supplementary information. Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Details of additional clinicians, organisations or agencies who require copies of any communication.
Additional detail about the service requested.
For example: Specimen details for a laboratory test request, or anatomical location for a procedure request.
Narrative description about the service requested.
This data point should be used to describe the named service in more detail, including how it should be delivered, patient concerns and issues that might be encountered in delivering the service.
The request does not require prioritised scheduling.
Details about the clinician or organisation requesting the service.
Details about the clinician or organisation receiving the request for service.
The date/time that marks the conclusion of the clinically valid period of time for delivery of this service.

This date/time is the equivalent to the latest possible date for service delivery or to the date of expiry for this request. For example: a service may be required to be completed before another event, such as scheduled surgery.
The date/time that marks the beginning of the valid period of time for delivery of this service.

This date/time is the equivalent to the earliest possible date for service delivery. For example: sometimes a certain amount of time must pass before a service can be performed, for example some procedures can only be performed once the patient has stopped taking medications for a specific amount of time.
The valid period for this request is open ended and has no date of expiry.
Record as TRUE to record explicity that the request has no expiry date. For example: commonly required for a referral to a specialist for long-term or lifelong care.

Coding of the 'Service type' with a coding system is desirable, if available. If the 'Service name' was coded, it is possible for this data point to be derived from the code. For example: biochemistry or microbiology laboratory, ultrasound or CT imaging.
Digital document, image, video or diagram supplied as additional information to support or inform the request.
Additional narrative about the service request not captured in other fields.
Details about a complex service request requiring a sequence of timings.
For example: 'hourly vital signs observations for 4 hours, then 4 hourly for 20 hours' or 'every third Wednesday for 3 visits' or .
The clinical reason for the ordered service.
Coding of the clinical indication with a terminology is preferred, where possible. This data element allows multiple occurrences. For example: 'Angina' or 'Type 1 Diabetes mellitus'.
Details about a single identified health condition, injury, disability or any other issue which impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual.

Clear delineation between the scope of a problem versus a diagnosis is not easy to achieve in practice. For the purposes of clinical documentation with this archetype, problem and diagnosis are regarded as a continuum, with increasing levels of detail and supportive evidence usually providing weight towards the label of 'diagnosis'.
Identification of the problem or diagnosis, by name.
Coding of the name of the problem or diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Estimated or actual date/time the diagnosis or problem was recognised by a healthcare professional.

Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of clinical recognition" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.
An assessment of the overall severity of the problem or diagnosis.

If severity is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant. Note: more specific grading of severity can be recorded using the Specific details SLOT.
Narrative description about the problem or diagnosis.
Use to provide background and context, including evolution, episodes or exacerbations, progress and any other relevant details, about the problem or diagnosis.
Identification of a simple body site for the location of the problem or diagnosis.

Coding of the name of the anatomical location with a terminology is preferred, where possible. Use this data element to record precoordinated anatomical locations. If the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations then use the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location within the 'Structured anatomical location' SLOT in this archetype. Occurrences for this data element are unbounded to allow for clinical scenarios such as describing a rash in multiple locations but where all of the other attributes are identical. If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant.
Estimated or actual date/time of resolution or remission for this problem or diagnosis, as determined by a healthcare professional.

Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of resolution" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.
A structured anatomical location for the problem or diagnosis.

Use this SLOT to insert the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location archetypes if the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations.
If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, use of this SLOT becomes redundant.
Details that are additionally required to record as unique attributes of this problem or diagnosis.

May include structured detail about the grading or staging of the diagnosis; diagnostic criteria, classification criteria or formal severity assessments such as Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events.
Structured details for location-, domain-, episode- or workflow-specific aspects of the diagnostic process.

Use status or context qualifiers with care, as they are variably used in practice and interoperability cannot be assured unless usage is clearly defined with the community of use. For example: active status - active, inactive, resolved, in remission; evolution status - initial, interim/working, final; temporal status - current, past; episodicity status - first, new, ongoing; admission status - admission, discharge; or priority status - primary, secondary.
The problem or diagnosis does not interfere with normal activity or may cause damage to health if left untreated.
The problem or diagnosis causes interference with normal activity or will damage health if left untreated.
The problem or diagnosis prevents normal activity or will seriously damage health if left untreated.
Additional narrative about the problem or diagnosis not captured in other fields.
The date this problem or diagnosis was last updated.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Narrative description about the course of the problem or diagnosis since onset.
The level of confidence in the identification of the diagnosis.
The diagnosis has been identified with a low level of certainty.
The diagnosis has been identified with a high level of certainty.
The diagnosis has been confirmed against recognised criteria.
Estimated or actual date/time that signs or symptoms of the problem/diagnosis were first observed.
Data captured/imported as "Age at onset" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.
Interaction, contact or care event between a subject of care and healthcare provider(s).
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
e.g. Local hospital departmental infomation or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.

items.items: *Interaction, contact or care event between a subject of care and healthcare provider(s). (en)
*Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms. (en)
*e.g. Local hospital departmental infomation or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents. (en)
*Very heavy menstrual flow, often causing additional problems such as flooding and clotting. (en)
*Record information about a menstural cyclea single day within a menstrual cycle. (en)
*Date of onset of menstrual bleeding in a single cycle. (en)
*End date of menstrual bleeding in a single cycle. (en)
*Details of menstrual bleeding/symptoms on a specific day, eg in a menstrual diary. (en)

*Duration of menstrual bleeding in a single cycle or typical duration over many cycles. (en)
*Length of single menstrual cycle or typical length over many cycles. (en)
*Narrative description of the menstrual cycle as a whole. (en)
*Qualitative description of amount of menstrual flow. (en)
*Presence of blood clots in the menstrual flow. (en)

Menoragija je strokovno poimenovanje za preobilne ali dolgotrajne menstruacije, ki se lahko pojavijo pri mladostnicah. Najpogosteje je to posledica hormonskega neravnovesja, kljub temu pa mora ginekolog preveriti, ali gre mogoÄe za zunajmaterniÄno ali materniÄno noseÄnost ali okuÅ¾bo. MoÄna menstruacija, ki je ne zadrÅ¾ijo/absorbirajo sanitarni pripomoÄki.

*Details of typical menstrual pattern over multiple cycles. (en)
*Use of napkin suited for heavy menstrual flow. (en)
*Use of a napkin suited for 'normal' menstrual flow. (en)
*Use of a napkin suited to very light menstrual flow or spotting. (en)
*Use of tampon suited for heavy menstrual flow. (en)
*Use of tampon suited for 'normal' menstrual flow. (en)
*Use of a cloth pad or towel. (en)
*Date of onset of menstrual bleeding in the last normal menstrual cycle. (en)

*The date when the woman last stopped using any type of contraception. (en)

*Date when the woman first used the specified type of contraception. (en)
*Can be a partial date, for example, only a year. (en)
*Additional narrative about all tobacco smoking that has not been captured in other fields. (en)

*The date this contraception summary was last updated. (en)
*Identification of the specific contraception used in this episode, by name. (en)

*Intended outcome anticipated as a result of use of the specified contraception. (en)
*For example: pregnancy prevention, regular cycle or relief of pain. (en)
*Additional structured details about the specified episode of contraception use. (en)
*Details about use of a specified type of contraception. (en)

*The run-time name constraint on this Cluster enables simple templates for each required type to be designed in templates, or the types to be managed exclusively at run-time. The list of names can be extended at run-time if additional types of contraception are identified locally. (en)
*Narrative description of the use for the specified type of contraception during this episode. (en)

*Narrative summary about the woman's overall use of contraception. (en)

*Use this data element to record a narrative description only where the structured data does not adequately reflect the use of contraception for this woman or to incorporate unstructured information from existing or legacy clinical systems into an archetyped format. (en)
*Statement about current use of the specified type of contraception. (en)
*Narrative summary about the use of the specified type of contraception. (en)
*An oral contraceptive pill containing both an oestrogen and progestin. (en)
*An oral contraceptive pill containing only a progestin was used. (en)

*Individual has previously used the specified type of contraception but is not a current user. (en)
*Individual is a current user of the specified type of contraception. (en)
*Details about a discrete period of use for the specified type of contraception. (en)
*Clinical reason for using the specified type of contraception during this episode. (en)

*Additional narrative about use of the specified type of contraception, not captured in other fields. (en)
*Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms. (en)
*For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents. (en)
*Narrative description for the reason for stopping use of the specified type of contraception during this episode. (en)
*For example: side effects or becoming pregnant. (en)
*The applied definition for the 'Current user' value in each of the 'Status' data elements used in this archetype. (en)
*The applied definition for the 'Former user' value in each of the 'Status' data elements used in this archetype. (en)
*Additional structured details about the specified type ofcontraception used. (en)
*The applied definition for the 'Never used' value in each of the 'Status' data elements used in this archetype. (en)
*Identification of an episode of contraception use - either as a number in a sequence and/or a named event. (en)
*For example: '2' as the second episode within a sequence of episodes; or 'Pregnancy with twins' if describing the smoking activity during a health event such as during a specific pregnancy. (en)
*Can be a partial date, for example, only a year. This data field will be empty if the episode is current and ongoing. (en)
*Additional structured details about the overall use of contraception. (en)
*Additional narrative about the use of the specified contraception during the specified episode, not captured in other fields. (en)
*Statement about current use of any type of contraception. (en)
*Individual has never used the specified type of contraception. (en)
*A depot injection of a progestogen was used. (en)
*An overview of the obstetric history of a woman, including a summary of all pregnancies and the associated outcomes or interventions. (en)
*Number of times a woman has been pregnant, including the current pregnancy, if appropriate. (en)
*Number of times a woman has given birth after 20 weeks and 0 days gestation. (en)

Late terminations of pregnancy (after 20 weeks of gestation) are not included. When both 'Term Births (T)' and 'Preterm Births (P)' are recorded, this number should be equal to their sum. Note: Parity is not regarded as the same as the number of infants born - for example, twins would be recorded as one birth event.
*Number of times a woman has had a miscarriage at less than 20 weeks of gestation. (en)
*Number of times a woman has had a pregnancy terminated, regardless of gestation. (en)
*The date this summary was last updated. (en)
Note: Stillbirth definition may be optionally captured in specific data element in Protocol.

Maybe useful to record when comparing data from different regions as, as definitions of stillbirth may vary. For example, in Australia a stillborn baby will have a gestation greater than 20 weeks or, if gestation is unknown, weigh more than 400 grams.

Record as TRUE if a woman has ever been pregnant. Only useful to record if there is no other detailed data about pregnancies available, or where it may be used to support further knowledge-based activities such as clinical decision support.
*Number of infants born on or after 37 weeks of gestation. (en)
*Number of infants born at less than 37 weeks of gestation. (en)
*Number of non-viable pregnancies from all causes and at any gestation, including miscarriages, induced terminations and ectopic pregnancies. (en)
When all of 'Miscarriages', 'Terminations' and 'Ectopic Pregnancies' are recorded, this number should be equal to their sum.
*Number of birth events in which more than one fetus has been born. (en)
*Narrative summary or overview about a patient, specifically from the perspective of a healthcare provider, and with or without associated interpretations. (en)
*The summary, assessment, conclusions or evaluation of the clinical findings. (en)
*Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms. (en)
*For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents. (en)
*Summary or persistent information about the tobacco smoking habit of an individual. (en)
*Individual is a current smoker of tobacco. (en)
*Individual has previously smoked tobacco but is not a current smoker. (en)
*Individual has never smoked any type of tobacco. (en)
Can be a partial date, for example, only a year.
*Date when the individual last smoked the specified type of tobacco. (en)

Can be a partial date, for example, only a year. Definitions for a 'Quit date' vary enormously and can be defined using the 'Quit data definition' data element in the Protocol section of this archetype. This date will be identical to the 'Episode end date' for the most recent episode. This date could be used by decision support guidance to determine if the individual is at risk of relapse, for example in the first 12 months since quitting.
*The date or partial date when the individual first started frequent or regular, but usually non-daily, smoking of tobacco of any type. (en)
Can be a partial date, for example, only a year. For example, this date could represent when the individual commenced smoking every Friday night or at parties.
*The date when the individual last ceased using tobacco of any type. (en)

Can be a partial date, for example, only a year. This date could be used by decision support guidance to determine if the individual is at risk of relapse, for example in the first 12 months since quitting.
*Estimate of the cumulative amount of tobacco smoked using the specified type of tobacco. (en)

Commonly used in assessment of cigarette use. It is calculated by multiplying the number of packs of cigarettes smoked per day by the number of years the individual has smoked. One pack year equals 365 packs of cigarettes. Details about how to calculate pack years for other types of tobacco can be found at http://smokingpackyears.com. The definition of a pack can be recorded in the protocol of this archetype using the 'Pack definition' data element.
*Additional narrative about all tobacco smoking that has not been captured in other fields. (en)
For example: stopped smoking or reduced amount on becoming pregnant.
*The date this tobacco smoking summary was last updated. (en)
*Estimate of number of units of the specified type of tobacco consumed. (en)
For example: the number of 'sticks' or 'full pipes' per day or per week. This data element is redundant if a value is recorded for 'Typical use(mass)'.
*Total number of times the individual has attempted to stop smoking the specified type of tobacco within this episode. (en)
*Additional structured details about the specified episode of tobacco smoking. (en)
*Details about smoking activity for a specified type of inhaled tobacco. (en)

The run-time name constraint on this Cluster enables simple templates for each required type to be designed in templates, or the types to be managed exclusively at run-time. The list of names can be extended at run-time if additional types of tobacco smoking are identified locally.
*The typical pattern of smoking for the specified type of tobacco. (en)
*Narrative summary about the individual's overall tobacco smoking pattern and history. (en)

Use this data element to record a narrative description only where the structured data does not adequately reflect the tobacco smoking habits for this individual or to incorporate unstructured tobacco smoking information from existing or legacy clinical systems into an archetyped format.
*Statement about current smoking behaviour for the specified type of tobacco. (en)
*Narrative summary about smoking behaviour for the specified type of tobacco. (en)

*Also known as manufactured cigarettes, 'factory made' cigarettes or 'tailor made' cigarettes. Processed tobacco, manufactured into cylinder made of paper or a substance that does not contain tobacco. (en)
*Also known as "rollies" or "roll-ups". Loose tobacco, hand rolled into a cylinder using cigarette papers. (en)
*Also known as "large cigar". Roll of tobacco wrapped within a leaf tobacco or in a substance that contains tobacco. (en)
*Loose tobacco placed inside a pipe bowl. (en)
*Individual has previously smoked the specified type of tobacco but is not a current smoker. (en)
*Individual is a current smoker of the specified type of tobacco. (en)
*Also known as "hookah", "shisha", "narguileh" and "hubble-bubble". Tobacco, often flavoured, is burned then cooled through a basin of water and consumed through a hose and mouthpiece. (en)
*Details about a discrete period of smoking activity for the specified type of tobacco. (en)
*Estimate of the weight of loose leaf tobacco smoked. (en)
This data element will typically be used for pipes and hand-rolled cigarettes and is redundant if a value is recorded for 'Typical use (units)'.
*Also known as mini cigars. Short and narrow cigar. (en)
*Additional narrative about smoking of the specified type of tobacco, not captured in other fields. (en)
*The applied definition for the 'Quit date' data elements used in this archetype. (en)
*The definition of the size of pack used as part of the algorithm for calculating 'Pack years' data elements used in this archetype. (en)

Definition may need to be specified per type. For example, the number of units in a pack used for cigarettes may be different to cigars; the mass of loose tobacco in a pack used for hand-rolled cigarettes or pipes.
*Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms. (en)
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
*Estimate of the cumulative amount for all types of tobacco smoked. (en)
The definition of a pack can be recorded in the protocol of this archetype using the 'Pack definition' data element.
*The applied definition for the 'Current smoker' value in each of the 'Status' data elements used in this archetype. (en)

Definition may need to be specified per type. Current smoker definitions vary in different jurisdictions. For example: USA Centre for Disease Control refers to smoking during the past one month and New Zealand Ministry of Health uses 28 days.
*The applied definition for the 'Former smoker' value in each of the 'Status' data elements used in this archetype. (en)
Definition may need to be specified per type. Former smoker definitions vary in different jurisdictions. For example: New Zealand Ministry of Health refers to smoking during the past 28 days.
*Additional structured details about the specified type of tobacco smoking. (en)
*Also known as Beedis. Thin hand-rolled cigarettes filled with tobacco and wrapped in a leaf, often tied with colorful string at one or both ends. They can be flavoured or unflavoured. (en)
Additional details could be recorded using the Fagerstrom
*The applied definition for the 'Never smoked' value in each of the 'Status' data elements used in this archetype. (en)
Definition may need to be specified per type. For example, the definition may not be zero, but less than a specified amount (as units or mass) smoked during a specified time interval.
*The date or partial date when the individual first started daily smoking of tobacco of any type. (en)
Can be a partial date, for example, only a year.
*Identification of an episode of smoking activity - either as a number in a sequence and/or a named event. (en)
For example: '2' as the second episode within a sequence of episodes; or 'Pregnancy with twins' if describing the smoking activity during a health event such as during a specific pregnancy.
Can be a partial date, for example, only a year. This data field will be empty if the episode is current and ongoing.
*Smoking the specified type of tobacco at least once every day. (en)
*Not smoking the specified type of tobacco every day. (en)
*The applied definition for a Quit attempt used to determine value for the 'Number of quit attempts' data element used in this archetype. (en)
For example: 'stopped smoking for one day or longer with the intention of quitting'.
*Additional structured details about the overall tobacco smoking behaviour. (en)
*Additional narrative about tobacco smoking during the specified episode, not captured in other fields. (en)
*Also known as clove cigarettes. Cigarettes that contain a mixture of tobacco, cloves and other additives. (en)
*Statement about current smoking behaviour for all types of tobacco. (en)
*Individual has never smoked the specified type of tobacco. (en)
*Request for a health-related service or activity to be delivered by a clinician, organisation or agency. (en)
*The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system. (en)
Usually equivalent to the HL7 Placer Order Identifier.
*The local identifier assigned to the request by the clinician or organisation receiving the request for service. (en)
Usually equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Identifier.
*The date/time, or acceptable interval of date/time, for provision of the service. (en)

This data element allows for recording of the timing for a single service, either as a date and time, a date ranges or a text descriptor which can allow for 'next available. In practice, clinicians will often think in terms of ordering services as approximate timing, for example: review in 3 months, 6 months or 12 months. As clinical systems need more exact parameters to operate on, this '3 months' will usually be converted to an exact date 3 months from the date of recording and stored using this data element. If complex timing or sequences of timings are required, use the CLUSTER.service_direction archetype within the 'Complex timing' SLOT and this data element becomes redundant.
*A short phrase describing the reason for the request. (en)

Coding of the 'Reason for request' with a coding system is desirable, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required. For example: 'manage diabetes complications'.
*Narrative description about the reason for request. (en)
For example: 'The patient's diabetes has recently become more difficult to stabilise and renal function is deteriorating'.
*Description of the intent for the request. (en)

For example: a referral to a specialist may have the intent of the specialist taking over responsibility for care of the patient, or it may be to provide a second opinion on treatment options. Coding of the 'Intent' with a coding system is desirable, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required.

Specific definitions of emergency and urgent will vary between clinical contexts, clinical systems and the nature of the request itself, so have not been defined in this archetype. If explicit timing is required then the Service period should be clearly stated.
Record as TRUE if additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available. For example: pending test results.
*Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms. (en)
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
*Language, transport or other personal requirements to support the patient's attendance or participation in provision of the service. (en)
*The name of the single service or activity requested. (en)
Coding of the 'Service name' with a coding system is desirable, if available. For example: 'referral' to an endocrinologist for diabetes management.
*The status of the request for service as indicated by the requester. (en)
Status is used to denote whether this is the initial request, or a follow-up request to change or provide supplementary information. Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
*Details of additional clinicians, organisations or agencies who require copies of any communication. (en)
For example: Specimen details for a laboratory test request, or anatomical location for a procedure request.
This data point should be used to describe the named service in more detail, including how it should be delivered, patient concerns and issues that might be encountered in delivering the service.
*The request does not require prioritised scheduling. (en)
*Details about the clinician or organisation requesting the service. (en)
*Details about the clinician or organisation receiving the request for service. (en)
*The date/time that marks the conclusion of the clinically valid period of time for delivery of this service. (en)

This date/time is the equivalent to the latest possible date for service delivery or to the date of expiry for this request. For example: a service may be required to be completed before another event, such as scheduled surgery.
*The date/time that marks the beginning of the valid period of time for delivery of this service. (en)

This date/time is the equivalent to the earliest possible date for service delivery. For example: sometimes a certain amount of time must pass before a service can be performed, for example some procedures can only be performed once the patient has stopped taking medications for a specific amount of time.
*The valid period for this request is open ended and has no date of expiry. (en)
Record as TRUE to record explicity that the request has no expiry date. For example: commonly required for a referral to a specialist for long-term or lifelong care.

Coding of the 'Service type' with a coding system is desirable, if available. If the 'Service name' was coded, it is possible for this data point to be derived from the code. For example: biochemistry or microbiology laboratory, ultrasound or CT imaging.
*Digital document, image, video or diagram supplied as additional information to support or inform the request. (en)
*Additional narrative about the service request not captured in other fields. (en)
*Details about a complex service request requiring a sequence of timings. (en)
For example: 'hourly vital signs observations for 4 hours, then 4 hourly for 20 hours' or 'every third Wednesday for 3 visits' or .
*The clinical reason for the ordered service. (en)
Coding of the clinical indication with a terminology is preferred, where possible. This data element allows multiple occurrences. For example: 'Angina' or 'Type 1 Diabetes mellitus'.
*Details about a single identified health condition, injury, disability or any other issue which impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual. (en)

Clear delineation between the scope of a problem versus a diagnosis is not easy to achieve in practice. For the purposes of clinical documentation with this archetype, problem and diagnosis are regarded as a continuum, with increasing levels of detail and supportive evidence usually providing weight towards the label of 'diagnosis'.
*Identification of the problem or diagnosis, by name. (en)
Coding of the name of the problem or diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
*Estimated or actual date/time the diagnosis or problem was recognised by a healthcare professional. (en)

Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of clinical recognition" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.
*An assessment of the overall severity of the problem or diagnosis. (en)

If severity is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant. Note: more specific grading of severity can be recorded using the Specific details SLOT.
*Narrative description about the problem or diagnosis. (en)
Use to provide background and context, including evolution, episodes or exacerbations, progress and any other relevant details, about the problem or diagnosis.
*Identification of a simple body site for the location of the problem or diagnosis. (en)

Coding of the name of the anatomical location with a terminology is preferred, where possible. Use this data element to record precoordinated anatomical locations. If the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations then use the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location within the 'Structured anatomical location' SLOT in this archetype. Occurrences for this data element are unbounded to allow for clinical scenarios such as describing a rash in multiple locations but where all of the other attributes are identical. If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant.
*Estimated or actual date/time of resolution or remission for this problem or diagnosis, as determined by a healthcare professional. (en)

Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of resolution" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.
*A structured anatomical location for the problem or diagnosis. (en)

Use this SLOT to insert the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location archetypes if the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations.
If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, use of this SLOT becomes redundant.
*Details that are additionally required to record as unique attributes of this problem or diagnosis. (en)

May include structured detail about the grading or staging of the diagnosis; diagnostic criteria, classification criteria or formal severity assessments such as Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events.
*Structured details for location-, domain-, episode- or workflow-specific aspects of the diagnostic process. (en)

Use status or context qualifiers with care, as they are variably used in practice and interoperability cannot be assured unless usage is clearly defined with the community of use. For example: active status - active, inactive, resolved, in remission; evolution status - initial, interim/working, final; temporal status - current, past; episodicity status - first, new, ongoing; admission status - admission, discharge; or priority status - primary, secondary.
*The problem or diagnosis does not interfere with normal activity or may cause damage to health if left untreated. (en)
*The problem or diagnosis causes interference with normal activity or will damage health if left untreated. (en)
*The problem or diagnosis prevents normal activity or will seriously damage health if left untreated. (en)
*Additional narrative about the problem or diagnosis not captured in other fields. (en)
*The date this problem or diagnosis was last updated. (en)
*Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms. (en)
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
*Narrative description about the course of the problem or diagnosis since onset. (en)
*The level of confidence in the identification of the diagnosis. (en)
*The diagnosis has been identified with a low level of certainty. (en)
*The diagnosis has been identified with a high level of certainty. (en)
*The diagnosis has been confirmed against recognised criteria. (en)
*Estimated or actual date/time that signs or symptoms of the problem/diagnosis were first observed. (en)
Data captured/imported as "Age at onset" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.
*Details about a contact person within organisation. (en)
*Professional demographics details including name(s) , addresse(s) and telecommunication contact details. (en)
*The employment grade or position of the carer. (en)
*The period during which this professional was involved in care of the subject. (en)
*Organisation details to which the individual is attached. (en)
*Details of personal name of an individual, provider or third party. (en)
*Name given to this person at birth. (en)
*Name used by this persion before marriage. (en)
*The date interval at which this name was valid. (en)
*The prefix or title used by the subject. (en)
*Additional term used following a person name. (en)
*The name used by the subject for business or professional purposes. (en)
*The name by which the subject is officially registered. (en)
*The subjectâs name as it is to be used for reporting, when used with a specific identifier. (en)
*Indicates that this is the name by which a person chooses to be identified. (en)
